20101231031019.000|20101231031021.000|TR0|WASHINGTON UNIVERSITY:  Well, I think much

20101231031025.000|20101231031027.000|TR0|

20101231032025.000|20101231032027.000|TR0|COOPER:  Tonight, what happens when a

20101231032029.000|20101231032031.000|TR0|corporations in the world team up to build 
20101231032031.000|20101231032033.000|TR0|a virtual fence.  Well, what happens is 
20101231032033.000|20101231032036.000|TR0|you get a lot of promises, a lot of bills 
20101231032036.000|20101231032038.000|TR0|and, in this case, not a whole lot of 
20101231032038.000|20101231032040.000|TR0|fence.
20101231032040.000|20101231032042.000|TR0|
20101231032042.000|20101231032044.000|TR0|It was supposed to be the big fix in 
20101231032044.000|20101231032046.000|TR0|border security:  a virtual fence, a 
20101231032046.000|20101231032048.000|TR0|high-tech system that would all but stop 
20101231032048.000|20101231032051.000|TR0|illegal immigration through surveillance, 
20101231032051.000|20101231032053.000|TR0|ground sensors, radar, the works.  It was 
20101231032053.000|20101231032055.000|TR0|supposed to be in place in working order 
20101231032055.000|20101231032057.000|TR0|by now.  The project started under 
20101231032057.000|20101231032059.000|TR0|President Bush back in 2006.
20101231032059.000|20101231032101.000|TR0|
20101231032101.000|20101231032103.000|TR0|But four years, $850 million of taxpayer 
20101231032103.000|20101231032105.000|TR0|money later, the virtual fence is a 
20101231032105.000|20101231032108.000|TR0|virtual disaster, a huge waste of time and 
20101231032108.000|20101231032110.000|TR0|money, tied up in bureaucracy and a

20101231032112.000|20101231032114.000|TR0|Homeland Security and Boeing.  They both, 
20101231032114.000|20101231032116.000|TR0|apparently, bungled the project, but 
20101231032116.000|20101231032118.000|TR0|tonight we're "Keeping Them Honest."
20101231032118.000|20101231032120.000|TR0|
20101231032120.000|20101231032123.000|TR0|Let's take a look at the plan.  Boeing got 
20101231032123.000|20101231032125.000|TR0|the contract to build this virtual fence 
20101231032125.000|20101231032127.000|TR0|back in September of 2006.  Now, according 
20101231032127.000|20101231032129.000|TR0|to a report by the GAO, the Government 
20101231032129.000|20101231032131.000|TR0|Accountability Office, just three months 
20101231032131.000|20101231032133.000|TR0|later the Department of Homeland Security 
20101231032133.000|20101231032135.000|TR0|said by the end of 2009 the entire 
20101231032135.000|20101231032137.000|TR0|northern and southern western borders of 
20101231032137.000|20101231032140.000|TR0|the U.S., a total of 6,000 miles, would be 
20101231032140.000|20101231032142.000|TR0|covered by the fence.
20101231032142.000|20101231032144.000|TR0|
20101231032144.000|20101231032146.000|TR0|Well, late in 2008 that projection was 
20101231032146.000|20101231032148.000|TR0|scaled back, forgetting about the northern

20101231032152.000|20101231032155.000|TR0|border completed by mid-2011.
20101231032155.000|20101231032157.000|TR0|

20101231032207.000|20101231032209.000|TR0|Arizona and even that is said to be not 
20101231032209.000|20101231032212.000|TR0|working all that well.  One problem, the

20101231034659.000|20101231034701.000|TR0|of take over, yet you do this very

20101231034748.000|20101231034750.000|TR0|BRADT:  When -- when I was growing up 
20101231034750.000|20101231034752.000|TR0|kayaking, a very tall waterfall was 70, 
20101231034752.000|20101231034754.000|TR0|80-feet tall.  I ran one 107 feet tall.

20101231034756.000|20101231034759.000|TR0|Palouse.  And when I looked at Palouse, it

20101231034809.000|20101231034811.000|TR0|And so I think that I ran it more because 
20101231034811.000|20101231034814.000|TR0|I thought I could.  I saw it.  I saw that

20101231034818.000|20101231034820.000|TR0|safely.  And luckily, it went exactly as

20101231034822.000|20101231034824.000|TR0|
20101231034824.000|20101231034826.000|TR0|GUPTA:  I think we're looking at some of 
20101231034826.000|20101231034828.000|TR0|the video.  Just now, you're dropping that 
20101231034828.000|20101231034831.000|TR0|much.  From what I understand you went 20 
20101231034831.000|20101231034833.000|TR0|feet down into the water, didn't come up 
20101231034833.000|20101231034835.000|TR0|for 20 seconds.  Do you remember what you 
20101231034835.000|20101231034837.000|TR0|were experiencing?  Obviously, you were 
20101231034837.000|20101231034839.000|TR0|falling, so you were experiencing that, 
20101231034839.000|20101231034841.000|TR0|but how did you not, like, you know, fall 
20101231034841.000|20101231034843.000|TR0|out of the kayak just from the momentum 
20101231034843.000|20101231034846.000|TR0|and the impact?
20101231034846.000|20101231034848.000|TR0|
20101231034848.000|20101231034850.000|TR0|BRADT:  Right.  I -- I invented a system 
20101231034850.000|20101231034852.000|TR0|that literally clamps me into the kayak.  
20101231034852.000|20101231034854.000|TR0|When breaking a record, it's necessary 
20101231034854.000|20101231034856.000|TR0|that you stay in the boat.  If you come 
20101231034856.000|20101231034858.000|TR0|out of the kayak, then it doesn't count.  
20101231034858.000|20101231034900.000|TR0|So it was full commitment for me.  I was 
20101231034900.000|20101231034903.000|TR0|committed on staying in my boat. I had 
20101231034903.000|20101231034905.000|TR0|this system that clamped my brace skirt 
20101231034905.000|20101231034907.000|TR0|onto the cockpit of the kayak to hold me 
20101231034907.000|20101231034909.000|TR0|in it.
20101231034909.000|20101231034911.000|TR0|

20101231034913.000|20101231034915.000|TR0|Through freefall, everything was going 
20101231034915.000|20101231034918.000|TR0|good.  I remember a very conscious 
20101231034918.000|20101231034920.000|TR0|positive thought go through my head, that 
20101231034920.000|20101231034922.000|TR0|this is going great, I'm exactly where I 
20101231034922.000|20101231034924.000|TR0|want to be.
20101231034924.000|20101231034926.000|TR0|
20101231034926.000|20101231034928.000|TR0|GUPTA:  While you're actually falling.
20101231034928.000|20101231034930.000|TR0|
20101231034930.000|20101231034932.000|TR0|BRADT:  Yes, while I'm falling.  My boat 
20101231034932.000|20101231034935.000|TR0|angle is right, which is the most 
20101231034935.000|20101231034937.000|TR0|important thing.
20101231034937.000|20101231034939.000|TR0|
20101231034939.000|20101231034941.000|TR0|GUPTA:  What is that?  Is that just 
20101231034941.000|20101231034943.000|TR0|straight down?
20101231034943.000|20101231034945.000|TR0|
20101231034945.000|20101231034947.000|TR0|BRADT:  Straight down.  It's a lot like 
20101231034947.000|20101231034950.000|TR0|jumping off a bridge or a rock.  You want 
20101231034950.000|20101231034952.000|TR0|to land feet first.  You don't want to 
20101231034952.000|20101231034954.000|TR0|land on your belly or off to one side.  
20101231034954.000|20101231034956.000|TR0|You want to penetrate into the water and 
20101231034956.000|20101231034958.000|TR0|decelerate over as long a period of time 
20101231034958.000|20101231035000.000|TR0|as possible.  That reduces the G-forces 
20101231035000.000|20101231035002.000|TR0|acting upon you, and that's what keeps you 
20101231035002.000|20101231035005.000|TR0|OK.
20101231035005.000|20101231035007.000|TR0|
20101231035007.000|20101231035009.000|TR0|GUPTA:  So instead of just stopping 
20101231035009.000|20101231035011.000|TR0|suddenly you're slowly going into the 
20101231035011.000|20101231035013.000|TR0|water.
20101231035013.000|20101231035015.000|TR0|
20101231035015.000|20101231035017.000|TR0|BRADT:  Exactly.  You want to go as deep 
20101231035017.000|20101231035019.000|TR0|as possible, slow down over as long a 
20101231035019.000|20101231035022.000|TR0|period of time as possible.  It's still a 
20101231035022.000|20101231035024.000|TR0|ferocious impact.  The biggest impact of 
20101231035024.000|20101231035026.000|TR0|my life, and I was completely dazed right 
20101231035026.000|20101231035028.000|TR0|upon impact.
20101231035028.000|20101231035030.000|TR0|
20101231035030.000|20101231035032.000|TR0|GUPTA:  Was that the scariest, one of the 
20101231035032.000|20101231035034.000|TR0|scariest moments?  Or if not, what was?
20101231035034.000|20101231035037.000|TR0|
20101231035037.000|20101231035039.000|TR0|BRADT:  The scariest moment is always when 
20101231035039.000|20101231035041.000|TR0|you're making the decision to do it.  
20101231035041.000|20101231035043.000|TR0|After you've made the decision to run 
20101231035043.000|20101231035045.000|TR0|something, you're getting in your kayak, 
20101231035045.000|20101231035047.000|TR0|you're getting ready to do it, you have to 
20101231035047.000|20101231035049.000|TR0|put that fear aside.  You have to be able 
20101231035049.000|20101231035051.000|TR0|to focus exactly on what you're doing.
20101231035051.000|20101231035054.000|TR0|
20101231035054.000|20101231035056.000|TR0|If you second guess yourself when you're 
20101231035056.000|20101231035058.000|TR0|doing something, if you have an "Oh, crap" 
20101231035058.000|20101231035100.000|TR0|moment right as you're going off the lip 
20101231035100.000|20101231035102.000|TR0|of this waterfall, chances are you're not 
20101231035102.000|20101231035104.000|TR0|going to react to what's going on right at 
20101231035104.000|20101231035106.000|TR0|that specific period of time.
20101231035106.000|20101231035109.000|TR0|
20101231035109.000|20101231035111.000|TR0|So it's necessary to put that fear in a 
20101231035111.000|20101231035113.000|TR0|box, place it to the side.  You know, be 
20101231035113.000|20101231035115.000|TR0|sure you have that fear there when you're 
20101231035115.000|20101231035117.000|TR0|making that decision, because that's what 
20101231035117.000|20101231035119.000|TR0|allows you to make the decision to run it 
20101231035119.000|20101231035121.000|TR0|and be safe, or be safe and walk away from 
20101231035121.000|20101231035123.000|TR0|it and be OK with that.  So fear's an 
20101231035123.000|20101231035126.000|TR0|important part, but you have to push it to 
20101231035126.000|20101231035128.000|TR0|the side when you're running it.
20101231035128.000|20101231035130.000|TR0|
20101231035130.000|20101231035132.000|TR0|GUPTA:  Everything you've just said now, 
20101231035132.000|20101231035134.000|TR0|have there been incidents where you 
20101231035134.000|20101231035136.000|TR0|realized during it now, not before, not 
20101231035136.000|20101231035138.000|TR0|when you've made the decision, but during 
20101231035138.000|20101231035141.000|TR0|the fact that -- the time you're running 
20101231035141.000|20101231035143.000|TR0|something, that it's not going well and 
20101231035143.000|20101231035145.000|TR0|you got scared?      BRADT:  There have 
20101231035145.000|20101231035147.000|TR0|been a couple of periods of time when I 
20101231035147.000|20101231035149.000|TR0|was obviously certainly scared kayaking.  
20101231035149.000|20101231035151.000|TR0|But I try to keep those to a minimum.
20101231035151.000|20101231035153.000|TR0|
20101231035153.000|20101231035155.000|TR0|GUPTA:  When you think about sort of next 
20101231035155.000|20101231035158.000|TR0|things for you, what if I told you that 
20101231035158.000|20101231035200.000|TR0|you can't kayak anymore?  That's something 
20101231035200.000|20101231035202.000|TR0|that can't be a part of your life.  What 
20101231035202.000|20101231035204.000|TR0|would that mean for you?
20101231035204.000|20101231035206.000|TR0|
20101231035206.000|20101231035208.000|TR0|BRADT:  Well, I would treat it as I treat 
20101231035208.000|20101231035210.000|TR0|everything in life.  I think that you can 
20101231035210.000|20101231035213.000|TR0|never pin something good or bad, because 
20101231035213.000|20101231035215.000|TR0|you don't know what outcome that's going 
20101231035215.000|20101231035217.000|TR0|to have on the rest of your life.  I would 
20101231035217.000|20101231035219.000|TR0|embrace it and accept it and move on and
